description: From Middle English agreable, from Old French agreable. Equivalent to agree +â€Ž -able.

adjectives.description: agreeable (comparative more agreeable, superlative most agreeable)

entries.meaning: Able to agree; possible to be agreed.
Pleasant to the senses or the mind.
examples: This fruit has an agreeable taste

entries.meaning: (dated) Willing; ready to agree or consent.
examples: These Frenchmen give unto the said captain of Calais a great sum of money, so that he will be but content and agreeable that they may enter into the said town.

entries.meaning: Agreeing or suitable; followed by to, or rarely by with.

examples: Agreeable to the order of the day, the House took up the report.

entries.meaning: Something pleasing; anything that is agreeable.
examples: The disagreeables of travelling are necessary evils, to be encountered for the sake of the agreeables of resting and looking round you.
